ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
NEW FRANCHISE TO MALAYAN
AIRWAYS LIMITED


    Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Minister for Communications and Works what is the position of the new franchise to be granted to Malayan Airways Limited; when can the House expect that its terms and conditions will be communicated to it; and whether the Government will initiate a debate in the Assembly in respect thereof.

    Mr Francis Thomas: The position as to a new franchise is at present somewhat uncertain. We have been unable as yet to reach a conclusion regarding the new franchise and have already had to extend the old franchise up to 31st

Column: 2208

July, 1957 in order to continue negotiations about the future structure and services of Malayan Airways. It has now become clear that a further extension will be necessary.

    I might explain that early this year we had reached a point at which the signing of a new agreement and the holding of a debate in the Assembly in connection therewith appeared imminent. Since then, however, a situation has arisen which has made it necessary to review the action already taken and to study new factors, and new proposals made thereon, which affect the new agreement. Negotiations are still proceeding in the light of these new proposals. For this reason, and also because the matter involves five Governments as well as the airline operators, I am unable to go into detail.

    I can, however, properly say that the new factors and the new proposals to which I have referred have raised issues of sufficient importance to warrant the holding of personal discussions between the five Governments and the airline operators at a high level, and hon. Members will doubtless have read in the local Press that these took place in Singapore on 15th and 16th July. They have been adjourned till about 9th or 10th August. If by that date the negotiations can be successfully completed - and I most sincerely hope that they will be - certain other action will remain to be taken both by the Government and by the airline operators in connection with the structure of the new company. It is generally agreed that the whole operation will require a further three-and-a-half or four months to complete. Action is therefore being taken to extend the present agreement for a yet further period up to 30th November, 1957.

    I can assure the House that we are pressing on with the utmost urgency and as soon as possible the House will have an opportunity of debating matters connected with the new agreement before it is signed.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Chairman, I beg to move an amendment,

    In page 17, line 14, after "Ordinance", to insert- ":

    Provided that no alteration shall be made in the boundaries of the electoral divisions of any local government area unless and until the proposed alteration has been notified in four successive Gazettes and contemporaneously advertised once every week for four consecutive weeks in one English,

one Chinese, one Malay and one Tamil newspaper circulating in the Colony with an invitation to all persons affected, by such alteration and who object thereto to make their objections known in writing to the Minister in order that the same may be duly considered by him:

Ord. 26       And  provided also that the provisions

of 1948.    of this  section shall  apply in respect

            District Councils.".


    Mr Chairman, there are three parts to the amendment which I have just read out. The original clause as it stands states quite clearly that as far as the boundaries of electoral divisions in local government areas are concerned the Minister has complete and unfettered authority to fix them as he thinks fit, and subsequently to alter them as he thinks fit. The clause as it stands at the moment reads:

    "The Minister may, from time to time, by notification published in the Gazette specify the names and boundaries of the electoral divisions of any local government area for purposes of elections under this Ordinance."

    Now the first part of our amendment is exactly parallel to the proviso to clauses 5 and 15 of the Local Government Bill in respect of the limits of the City and District Council boundaries. It requires that when any alterations are made in future to the electoral division boundaries, notification must be made in the Gazette for four consecutive weeks and in newspapers in the four main languages. In countering our arguments on this point last week, the Hon. the Chief Secretary was not in his most thoughtful frame of mind. He said - and I hope I do not misrepresent him in his absence - that this matter was not raised in the Select Committee as being one of importance and why therefore should it be raised now? The answer is simple. We had formed the impression that as an All-Party Committee was to be set up to work out Legislative Assembly electoral boundaries, the same principle would be

Column: 2211

applied by the Government in respect of local government boundaries. As we are now faced with a virtual fait accompli by the strict application of this clause 8, it is only right and proper that at this stage we should move an amendment to draw attention to, and if possible prevent, a fait accompli.

    Secondly, the whole point of recommitting clauses or whole Bills to a Committee of this Assembly is that there should be second thoughts on important legislation. The Hon. the Minister is still bringing in fresh amendments to the Local Government Bill, matters which have been overlooked or left out. Is he to be criticised for introducing amendments at the eleventh hour? Or is he to be commended for noticing them in time? We have had second thoughts on this particular clause, as we are entitled to have them, and we find these amendments to be most vital.

    The Hon. the Chief Secretary went on to say that electoral division boundaries were not important to the man-in-the-street and that so long as he got a vote he did not mind where he voted. I am surprised at my Hon. Friend taking such a light-hearted attitude in this matter which strikes at the root of all democratic principles. Political Parties and Independent Members and individual responsible citizens and the Press are there to see that electoral division boundaries are delineated on a completely impartial basis, and they represent the man-in-the-street who may not always himself be articulate. In the United Kingdom an independent commission was set up four or five years ago to delineate new constituencies required by shifting populations and the growth of new towns for the last general elections in that country. This was done so that neither Conservatives nor Labour nor Liberal could say that the boundaries had been rigged. When the Hon. the Chief Secretary tried to make light of the whole problem we on this side have been forced to the conclusion that the Government has a guilty conscience in this matter. The louder they

Column: 2212

cry, "We never even thought of fixing the boundaries to suit our political convenience!", the less convincing their protestations are. That may be unfortunate but it is inevitable.

    As I said last week, if the Government does not accept the principle that the delineation of electoral divisions should be subject to public scrutiny and objections if necessary, then it lays itself open to the charge of political manipulation even if it is innocent, and that goes for any other government of the future.

    Let me go back to the first proviso in which lies the principle that alterations in future must be gazetted and advertised in four languages. The Government, if it is wise, will accept this principle with no difficulty whatever because it affects the future.

    The second and third provisos follow from the first. If the principle is accepted then it follows that it must be applied in respect of the alterations which are now being made, which are most extensive because this great new local government machinery is coming into operation for the first time. A huge new electorate of largely non-English-speaking people is now to be made interested in playing its part in local government administration through its elected representatives. The present six wards of the City Council are to be changed to at least 32. The District Council areas are to have between them eventually at least 48 divisions or wards. Are these great democratic changes to be thrust on the people in an undemocratic way, or are the people to be invited to comment on these changes through their Chinese, Tamil, Malay or English newspapers?

    We must begin, as we mean to go on, following proper principles. Government must not only be democratic but to be seen to be democratic. Now the Government, if it accepts the principle in the first proviso, need have no difficulty whatever in accepting the third proviso in respect of the District Councils because, as the Minister has told us, these elections cannot be held until

Column: 2213

March 1958 and therefore there is plenty of time to publish the boundaries and call for objections.

    The only doubt arising is the second proviso and whether gazetting and advertising the proposed boundaries of the City Council for objections will have caused the holding of elections to be delayed beyond December this year. There are, Sir, several answers to this. Firstly, the Government must never ward off or ignore criticism, or threaten postponement of elections as a reason for not accepting amendments. If the amendments are sound, but may cause delay, then delay must be accepted by all parties or a way found round that delay. Secondly, the Hon. the Chief Secretary himself said that minor changes could still be made. If that is so, the public have a right to express their views as to these changes. Thirdly, changes in boundaries do not affect the compiling of the list of voters, which is the biggest task. The electorate itself is the primary compilation; fitting them within the boundaries is secondary. Fourthly, if the Government feels that gazetting and advertising in the newspapers for four consecutive weeks would severely upset its programme of a December election, we on this side would be quite prepared to accept an amendment to this particular proviso to the effect that the boundaries be gazetted, say, twice and advertised four times within two weeks, with a further week for objections to be sent in.

    What kind of a time-table would this mean? Gazetting on Saturday, 3rd August to the 10th August, and the last day for objections say 17th August. This will not only give time to the All-Party Committee to study the boundaries but give Independents and individuals the chance to express their views. We have no doubt that if the Government wants to do this it can do it and still hold December elections.

    Mr Chairman, if we want to have clean elections we must start off in a clean way, with no suggestions or implications of Government having manipulated the divisions to suit its own interests. If the Government refuses to accept this amendment suspicions will be aroused inevitably, and corruption - which we all

Column: 2214

profess to want to see removed - will not be removed.

    Amendment to the Amendment handed in.

    The Chairman: The amendment is in order. Please proceed.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Chairman, Sir, I beg to move two amendments. The first is,

    At the beginning of the first proviso, to leave out "Provided that no" and insert "(2) And no".

The second amendment is,

    At the end of the first proviso, after "him" to leave out all words to the end and insert "provided that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply in respect of the first ordinary elections of Councillors to the City Council or to any District Council held under the provisions of this Ordinance.".

    Mr Chairman, the first amendment is consequential to the second amendment and I shall therefore take them both together and explain the second amendment. Government agrees in principle with the first proviso given in the amendment by the hon. Member for Tanglin. There are similar provisions in clauses 5 and 15 of the Local Government Bill. It is not agreed, however, that the present procedure envisaged should apply in respect of the first ordinary elections under this Ordinance. That is why I am moving this amendment. At this stage if boundaries are to be altered, all the work which has been done in the preparation of registers for electoral divisions showing the polling districts will have been wasted and the registers will have to be scrapped. As it is, Sir, more than half of the registers have been printed by the Printing Office. Elections would have to be postponed several months.

    At the last sitting of the Assembly the Hon. the Chief Secretary explained that the boundaries for City electoral divisions had been drawn up by officials without any direction. In spite of what the hon. Member for Tanglin has just said, Sir, I repeat once again that that is so. I should like to draw the attention of this House to the statement made by

Column: 2215

the hon. Member for Serangoon wherein not only did he cast an aspersion on the Government in power, but also on our civil service. Thank God, Sir, we have a first-class civil service which is above board, a civil service which cannot be influenced by the machinations of any political Party, even by the Party in power.

    This morning, Sir, for the information of Members of this Assembly I circulated the Report of the Committee which delineated the boundaries of the City Council. A perusal of that Report, Sir, will apprise Members of the basis upon which the electoral divisions were delineated.

    For the above reasons, Sir, I have to repeat once again that any alteration in the present boundaries as drawn up by the official Committee will involve delay in the holding of elections. Sir, I beg to move.

since when an amendment to the original amendment has been moved,

    firstly, to leave out the words "Provided that no" at the beginning of the first proviso and there to insert "(2) No", converting the first proviso into a subclause of the clause;

10.30 a.m.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Chairman, we welcome on this side the fact that the principle that alterations in electoral division

Column: 2216

boundaries should be gazetted and objections invited from the people of Singapore. But once you have accepted that principle you must apply it from the start. Take the second part of the amendment to the amendment - I see no reason whatever in the first place why this principle should not be accepted in respect of the District Councils. I mentioned that a few moments ago. You have much more time in the case of the District Councils. Therefore having accepted the principle in the first instance, accept it without hesitation in respect of the District Councils.

    We then come to the problem - we admit it is a problem - of the City Council electoral division boundaries and the need to hold the elections as soon as possible. In this regard it must be remembered, as the Hon. the Minister has just said, that the Report of the Committee which has worked out the delineation of these boundaries has only been placed in the hands of Members this morning and I presume supplied to the Press this morning. Why could this not have been done before? Why could not some machinery, say the All-Party Committee, have been put into operation to consider these boundaries at least two or three weeks ago? It would have been quite possible to do this. Then possibly there would have been no need to move this part of the amendment, as I call it the second proviso. We would have accepted the fact that the public and the All-Party Committee were being given a chance to consider these new boundaries.

    But no, we are faced with this Report today, on the very day in which we have to debate this important question. It could have been given to us earlier. I do not know why it was not. Will the Hon. the Minister therefore not accept our suggestion that if he cannot agree to four weeks of gazetting and advertising in the newspapers in respect of changes in the City Council boundaries, he will agree to reducing the length of time of gazetting in order that this important principle is accepted, which in fact Government has accepted through accepting my first proviso?

    The Acting Chief Secretary (Mr S. T. Stewart): Mr Chairman, Sir, in support of my friend and colleague, the Minister for Local Government, I have to say that the Statistics and Printing Departments are well on with preparing the electoral rolls for the City Council elections based on the City Council boundaries specified in the Local Government Bill and on the electoral divisions drawn up by the official Committee. Any change in the boundaries must of course delay the final certification of the electoral registers, and if the changes are major ones the effect will be more serious. For example, Sir, if Katong is restored to the City it will materially affect the total number of voters in the City Council area as it contains a large number of voters - I remember, Sir, roughly well over 25,000 voters.

    The electoral divisions have been based on the assumption that there will be a total of 505,000 names on the rolls altogether and the 32 divisions have been designed to divide this number as equally as possible. If the total number is increased it will probably be that all 32 divisions will have to be revised. If divisions adjoining the boundary of the City Council are altered there will almost certainly be repercussions throughout. Even a minor change of two electoral divisions - let us say Cairnhill and its Western neighbour, River Valley - must cause some delay, and the length of the delay will depend on the number of alterations to be made.

    If the first proviso given in the amendment of the Member for Tanglin is made applicable to the City and District Council electoral divisions, as suggested in the second and third provisos of the amendment, it will initially mean a delay of at least four to five weeks. If you read the first amendment, Sir, there will be an initial delay of four weeks and if the Minister is to consider the representations made it may mean another delay of one week or perhaps even more.

    Next, if any major change takes place, it will involve a further delay of three or four months, for the following reasons: (1) We have to rearrange the cards

Column: 2218

into new divisions and this will require, according to those who have to carry out this work, about 10 weeks; (2) to reproduce, collate and bind the registers will require another ten weeks; (3) assuming that a large part of these two territories overlap, at least 15 to 17 weeks will be required. If Katong is put back into the City and the rural area included in the Western part of the City area is taken out again, the recasting of the boundaries of all District Council areas will have to be undertaken.

    My hon. colleague said in this Assembly - I think it was at the April or May sitting, Sir - that it was intended to hold District Council elections in March 1958 if City Council elections are held in December 1957. One of the reasons, Sir, is that there cannot be simultaneous preparation of every phase in the drawing up of new District and City Council registers because the sorting machines and so forth can only be concentrated on one set of registers at a time. Therefore, Sir, if City Council elections have to be postponed to April/May 1958 then District Council elections will have to be postponed to June/July, or even August, 1958. I do not know whether we want that. I do not think we want that, Sir. I think the people of Singapore want to see the new City and District Councils in being as quickly as possible.

    We cannot afford any delay if elections are to be held in December. Since the electoral rolls should be published by the latter half of August in order to hold elections in December, the tentative time-table to which Government is working, based on the periods allowed for in the Bill, is as follows: (1) listing, printing, collating, binding and publication of draft registers to be completed by 20th August, 1957; (2) allowing for claims and objections to be completed from 21st August to 18th September, 1957; adjudication of claims and objections to be completed by 19th October; listing, printing, collating and insertion of amendments for claims and objections in the draft registers and certification of final registers by 31st October. Thus a

Column: 2219

writ of elections can be issued any time from 1st November, 1957 onwards and if it is found possible to publish draft registers before 20th August so much the better, Sir.

    Sir, for the reasons which I have given, I oppose the second and third provisos of the hon. Member's amendment. We want to try and hold to this time-table. We want to have these City Council elections in December and the District Council elections in March. I repeat again, Sir: the public of Singapore want these new Councils. For those reasons, Sir, I support the amendment moved by my hon. colleague.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Chairman, Sir, the last speaker has only one point to offer and that is, "We do not want to delay City Council elections." But let me ask this House, Sir, how long has Government delayed them? Has it not delayed them for at least one year? Did we not hear in this Assembly last year that it was going to postpone the City Council elections? I remember when the new Government took office it said it wanted to hold elections at a very early date but there have since been two postponements. I think I am right; there have two postponements of these elections.

    What has the Government been doing during these two years? I would like very much to know. Has it been working on the matter? Has it been trying hard to make early elections possible? It is always good to say that people want early elections. We want them early too, but it is a very different thing not to put it into practice. There was plenty of time on the hands of Government in the last two years and more, yet today we are confronted with the reason, "We do not want delays." Government could have made them earlier but it has not attempted to make it earlier. [Interruption].

that these delays could have been averted if it had started earlier.

    There is another one more point to consider. It would be better to have an election which is said by all to be fair, to be democratic, than to have one thrust down your throat just because Government says, "We cannot delay." Now that is like tempting you by saying, "If you want it this way you must have it my way. If you want to have elections in December then you must carry out elections on the lines we propose. If you do not carry out on the lines we propose then there will be no elections, and if there is going to be delay the blame will be on you." That is absolutely unfair. That is absolutely undemocratic. That amounts to coercion, Sir.

    And now how much will it cost the people of Singapore to change a little bit of this printing? Cost and labour should not be taken into consideration. The more important consideration is whether it is democratic, whether it is viewed by all to be fair. Since the Government, Sir, has accepted the first proviso, I see no reason why the third proviso should not have been accepted. People living in the City are important. They can have objections. They must be notified of changes. But I personally feel that people living in the rural areas are also as important, and that if one measure is given to the City people then it should also be given to people in the Districts. This will not be done if the amendment of the Minister is accepted to strike off the second and third provisos, the reason for opposing the second proviso being that if you are going to have alterations now to your City Council divisions you will not be able to have elections in December. Let me quote, Sir, from a note which I received this morning about the electoral divisions in the City proposed by the Government Committee. I happen also to have a copy of the Constituency Delineation Commission of the Federation of Malaya, and I shall also quote one or two extracts from that.

Now this is a terribly bad system, Sir, of compiling our electoral rolls. You put it to any man and if he can say that it is logical to have 4,000 odd voters when there are only 3,000 odd people living there, then something must be wrong. I would like to draw your attention further, Sir, to the fact that the 3,000 odd people are men, women and children combined, whereas the 4,000 odd voters are all over 21.
